author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Donors Worry About Fate of Artifacts as Museum on Irish Famine Closes
description: Quinnipiac University, which had opened Ireland’s Great Hunger Museum in 2012, said that it could no longer afford to operate it.
content: In the mid-1990s John L. Lahey, the president of Quinnipiac College, read a book about the 19th-century potato famine in Ireland and decided that its causes and consequences, its death toll and resulting diaspora, warranted broader exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Will the Vaccines Stop Omicron? Scientists Are Racing to Find Out.
description: A “Frankenstein mix” of mutations raises concerns, but the variant may remain vulnerable to current vaccines. If not, revisions will be necessary.
content: As nations severed air links from southern Africa amid fears of another global surge of the coronavirus, scientists scrambled on Sunday to gather data on the new Omicron variant, its capabilities and — perhaps most important — how effectively the current vaccines will protect against it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: An update on the Omicron variant.
content: The new coronavirus variant, first discovered in southern Africa, is showing up across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Shechet
title: This Fire-Loving Fungus Eats Charcoal, if It Must
description: Some fungi sprout in fiery shades of orange and pink after wildfires, feasting on what was left behind by the burn.
content: When a wildfire plows through a forest, life underground changes, too. Death comes for many microorganisms. But, like trees, some microbes are adapted to fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Why the Feminist Movement Needs Pro-Life People
description: We must form a broad and diverse coalition to advocate for women.
content: When I was a freshman in college, a professor asked our class to define the term “feminist.” We fell silent. I attended a broad-minded liberal arts school, so I assumed our professor was a feminist, but the word carried enough ambiguity and ideological baggage that I was uncertain what to say, and I was not sure if I was one. I am from a fairly conservative background, and my impression of feminism at the time was vague and conflicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Kiki and Herb Will Be Back Where They Belong for Christmas
description: Justin Vivian Bond and Kenny Mellman have resurrected their Christmas act for “a big, old chosen family reunion.”
content: Kiki and Herb, the glamorous and harrowing cabaret duo created by Justin Vivian Bond and Kenny Mellman, never performed as reliably as the Radio City Rockettes. But for a while in the early 2000s, no Christmas felt complete without them — especially if you are the kind of person who prefers a belt of Canadian Club to eggnog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The Netherlands finds at least 13 Omicron cases and expects more.
description: At least 13 people who arrived in the Netherlands on two flights from South Africa on Friday were infected with the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, and more cases will most likely be found, Dutch health officials said on Sunday.
content: At least 13 people who arrived in the Netherlands on two flights from South Africa on Friday were infected with the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, and more cases will most likely be found, Dutch health officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Omicron Is Coming. The U.S. Must Act Now.
description: South Africa gave the world an early warning. Decisive action on containment and surveillance could help us control it.
content: There’s very little we know for sure about Omicron, the Covid variant first detected in South Africa that has caused tremors of panic as winter approaches. That’s actually good news. Fast, honest work by South Africa has allowed the world to get on top of this variant even while clinical and epidemiological data is scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Lynsey Chutel
title: South Africa, where Omicron was detected, is an outlier on the least vaccinated continent.
description: The country has one of Africa’s better vaccination rates: Just under one-quarter of its population has been fully inoculated.
content: On the face of it, the emergence of the Omicron variant is the unhappy fulfillment of expert predictions that the failure to prioritize vaccinations for African countries would allow the coronavirus to continue to circulate and mutate there, imperiling the world’s ability to move beyond the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Local News Outlets Could Reap $1.7 Billion in Build Back Better Aid
description: A small paper like The Storm Lake Times in Iowa would receive a big tax credit. So would Gannett, the nation’s largest news publisher.
content: For The Storm Lake Times, a family-run paper in northwestern Iowa, it could mean $200,000 in federal subsidies the first year and nearly $500,000 over the four years after that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines were seeing a travel rebound before Omicron arrived.
description: With several countries imposing new restrictions, the question now is whether travelers will be deterred.
content: The discovery the Omicron variant comes at a delicate moment for an airline industry that was just starting to see a rebound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Mikaela Shiffrin Has a World Cup Record, and, Finally, a Rival
description: Shiffrin tied the career record for World Cup wins in a single discipline, slalom, beating Petra Vlhova of Slovakia, the sport’s reigning overall champion.
content: KILLINGTON, Vt. — The most enduring athletic careers are typically defined by a rivalry with an opponent of comparable talent or skill. Think Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: The Woman on the Bridge
description: Police and prosecutors spent five years chasing a domestic violence case. Would it be enough?
content: KITTERY, Maine — At 7:05 on an April evening five years ago, Ryan Sanford, a patrol officer in the port town of Kittery, got a call about a van driving erratically on Route 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Phil Saviano, Survivor of Clergy Sex Abuse, Dies at 69
description: He played a pivotal role in helping The Boston Globe uncover the widespread scandal in the Catholic Church and was portrayed in the movie “Spotlight.”
content: Phil Saviano carried a terrible secret for much of his life — that in the early 1960s, when he was 11, he was sexually molested by his parish priest in Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: First, I Cried. Then, I Rode My Bike.
description: Pedal, pedal, pedal, glide.
content: When I was about 5 or 6 years old, my mother set me down on a purple banana-seat bike. She gripped the back of the seat while I found my balance. Then she gave me a push and let me go, calling, “Pedal, pedal, pedal, glide!” as I rode across the lawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Hondurans seek a break from graft and despair in an election with repercussions for the United States.
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Hondurans voted Sunday in tense general elections that are likely to have repercussions far beyond the Central American country.
content: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Hondurans voted Sunday in tense general elections that are likely to have repercussions far beyond the Central American country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Iron Bowl Thriller Behind It, Alabama Prepares for No. 1 Georgia
description: Alabama is poised to move up a spot in the College Football Playoff rankings ahead of its Southeastern Conference title game against the Bulldogs.
content: AUBURN, Ala. — When it ended, the University of Alabama football players galloped across the field, gesturing mockingly at the stunned Auburn fans at Jordan-Hare Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: The Giants and Jets Both Won, but Which Team Was More Enjoyable?
description: It’s late in the N.F.L. season and both teams have been lifelessly bad. But the Jets, at least, offered a spark in beating the Houston Texans on Sunday.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Omicron, Iran, Stephen Sondheim: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 28, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about a film-production company focused on teen comedies misstated the given name of the 24-year-old man who now manages a team of script readers. He is Matt Sacca, not Will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Former Wright Brothers Bicycle Shop Faces Demolition
description: Officials in Dayton, Ohio, have given permission to raze the building, which they describe as dangerous and at risk of collapsing. Preservationists say parts of it can be saved.
content: In 1892, the brick building at 1005 West Third Street had several large windows that allowed the residents of Dayton, Ohio, to peek inside and see the Wright brothers, who were still years from becoming pioneers of flight, run their bicycle shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Uber Survived the Spying Scandal. Their Careers Didn’t.
description: A former co-worker accused the men of wiretapping their colleagues, hacking foreign governments and stealing trade secrets. It wasn’t true, but the allegations still follow them.
content: The men who gathered intelligence for Uber were supposed to be ghosts. For years, they were un-Googleable sentries, quietly informing executives about the actions of competitors, opponents and disgruntled employees. But the secrecy of the tightknit team ended abruptly in 2017 when one of its members turned on the others, accusing them of stealing trade secrets, wiretapping and destroying evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Giulia Heyward
title: Governors urge caution in the United States on the Omicron variant.
description: No cases of the new coronavirus variant have been confirmed in the U.S., but leaders said they were using existing safeguards and watching closely.
content: Governors across the United States tried to reassure Americans on Sunday that their administrations were closely monitoring the impact of a new coronavirus variant that has alarmed scientists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: When Is a Horror Movie Not a Horror Movie?
description: When “The Humans” and other new dramas use jump scares and other genre staples, it’s a fair question to ask.
content: A few days before Halloween, the @NetflixFilm Twitter account put out a call: “What movie isn’t technically a horror movie but feels like a horror movie to you?” Included was a photo of a freaky-eyed Gene Wilder in “Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Israel and Iran Widen Targets in a Cyberwar
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 28, 2021.
content: “There will be a next round of widespread cyberattack on our infrastructure. We are a step closer to military confrontation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: The W.H.O. skips forward two Greek letters, avoiding a Xi variant.
description: Under the World Health Organization’s system, the Omicron variant might have been called Nu or Xi, but only at the risk of ambiguity or diplomatic awkwardness.
content: When the World Health Organization began to name the emerging variants of the coronavirus, officials turned to the Greek alphabet to make it easier for the public to understand the evolution: Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta and so on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
description: No simultaneous streaming: “Encanto” or “House of Gucci” could only be seen in theaters this weekend. Even still, some viewers stayed home.
content: Hollywood has stopped running from the pandemic: For the first time since March 2020, movie theaters had a wide array of new films for exclusive screening over the holiday weekend. And studios did not hedge their bets by offering simultaneous streaming options. To see the gloriously reviewed “Encanto,” the campy crime drama “House of Gucci” or the latest installment in the “Resident Evil” science-fiction action franchise, you had to leave the sofa, just like in the old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Stephen Sondheim, as Great a Composer as He Was a Lyricist
description: Our chief classical music critic remembers playing and teaching the unforgettable scores of “Sweeney Todd,” “Sunday in the Park With George” and other shows.
content: “Sweeney Todd” had been open for a few months on Broadway when, one Saturday afternoon in June 1979, I passed by the theater where it was playing. I assumed that Stephen Sondheim’s latest musical was sold out, but I decided to take a chance and see if I could get a ticket to the matinee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. health officials urge vaccinations as Omicron spreads.
description: Getting a vaccination remains the best line of defense against Covid-19, the nation’s top two health leaders said on Sunday.
content: Top federal health officials in the United States urged unvaccinated Americans on Sunday to get their shots and for eligible adults to seek out boosters, as the discovery of a new variant sparked a new wave of travel restrictions and alarmed scientists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
description: After a year marked by isolation, loneliness and violence in the city, many self-defense and martial arts gyms say they are seeing more interest from women.
content: LONDON — The thwack of fists hitting hand pads echoed through the studio as pairs of women circled each other, striking blows and blocking them, with a singular focus. A solid jab from one woman elicited an approving murmur from her sweaty partner. Another ducked in anticipation of an incoming left hook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Sylvia Weinstock, the ‘da Vinci of Wedding Cakes,’ Dies at 91
description: She produced floral-draped architectural works in the shape of rose-studded topiaries, baskets of speckled lilies and bouquets of anemones.
content: Sylvia Weinstock, who took the art of baking to new heights with her 10-foot-tall wedding cakes and their garlands of hundreds, and sometimes thousands, of hand-painted sugar flowers,  died on Nov. 22 at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Preliminary results are expected by 8 p.m. local time.
description: Polls began wrapping up around 5 p.m. with few reports of problems so far.
content: Voting began at 7 a.m. and officially ended at 5 p.m., although the electoral council has urged polls to remain open if there are still people waiting to cast their ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Los hondureños buscan un alivio de la desesperación en unas elecciones con repercusiones para EE. UU.
description: Tegucigalpa, HONDURAS — Los hondureños votaron hoy en unas elecciones generales tensas, cuyas repercusiones podrían ir mucho más allá del país centroamericano.
content: Tegucigalpa, HONDURAS — Los hondureños votaron hoy en unas elecciones generales tensas, cuyas repercusiones podrían ir mucho más allá del país centroamericano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Esper Claims Defense Dept. Is Improperly Blocking Parts of His Memoir
description: The former defense secretary sued the agency, saying that portions of the book were being concealed “under the guise of classification.”
content: Former Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper on Sunday sued the agency he once led, accusing officials at the Pentagon of improperly blocking significant portions of an upcoming memoir about his tumultuous tenure under President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: As U.S. Hunts for Chinese Spies, University Scientists Warn of Backlash
description: A chilling effect has taken hold on American campuses, contributing to an outflow of academic talent that may hurt the United States while benefiting Beijing.
content: The F.B.I. agents spent nearly two years tailing the professor, following him to work, to the grocery store, and even keeping his college-age son under surveillance. They told the university where he held a tenured position that he was a Chinese operative, prompting the school to cooperate with their investigation and later fire him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: What’s at Stake in the Honduran Presidential Election?
description: Hondurans head to the polls on Sunday, but widespread political violence during the campaign and questionable results from 2017 are looming large.
content: Haz clic aquí para leer la cobertura en español de las elecciones en Honduras. Click here to read in English our coverage of the elections in Honduras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran
title: The Week in Business: Choosing the Same Path
description: President Biden opted for continuity at the Fed, nominating Jerome Powell to a second four-year term. And it’s that time of year — for travel and shopping.
content: On Monday, President Biden announced that he was renominating Jerome H. Powell for another four-year term as chair of the Federal Reserve, resisting pressure from progressive Democrats who wanted a change at the top of the Fed and instead choosing policy continuity. But in a move that could appease some of those progressives, Mr. Biden said he would nominate Lael Brainard as vice chair. The role could give her the power to influence everything from the cost of money to the future of digital cash. Mr. Powell, who is expected to receive bipartisan support for his Senate confirmation, will face the task of dismantling the extraordinary efforts the Fed took last year to keep the economy going during the depths of the pandemic. Now, the Fed will need to determine how to start raising interest rates, which have been just above zero since March 2020, without sending the economy into a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Laszlo Z. Bito, Scientist, Novelist and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
description: He fled communist rule in Hungary, discovered a treatment for glaucoma in the U.S., then became an author and a voice against authoritarianism in his homeland.
content: Laszlo Bito, a research scientist who fled communist oppression in Hungary, discovered a breakthrough treatment for glaucoma while at Columbia University and then returned to his homeland for a second career as a novelist, philanthropist and public intellectual, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Budapest. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: 20 Stephen Sondheim Songs to Listen to Right Now
description: The lyricist and composer, who died on Friday, wrote dozens of piercing tunes for Broadway. Here is a selection of his most brilliant and surprising.
content: The career of Stephen Sondheim, the celebrated Broadway songwriter who died on Friday at the age of 91, spanned decades and included 20 major productions, including forays into television and film. Here is one song from each of those 20 in chronological order, highlighting a genius that was evident from a jarringly early age (even if critics took a while to catch on) for mixing longing and ambivalence into clever, spiky, dependably unexpected lyrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Modern Love?
description: Enrique Henestroza Anguiano gets out ahead.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to the Monday crossword! I hope you all had a restful and pie-filled holiday weekend that prepared you for a bit of exercise in today's puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Man Survives Flight From Guatemala to Miami in Plane’s Landing Gear
description: The 26-year-old man, whose name was not released, was taken into custody by border agents, officials said.
content: A 26-year-old man survived a flight from Guatemala to Miami on Saturday after hiding in the airplane’s landing gear compartment, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: The Omicron variant upends the global pandemic response.
description: Britain, Israel and others announced new restrictions as some health experts urged caution.
content: Scientists raced to study a new coronavirus variant as several cases were spotted in Europe and governments around the world announced travel restrictions targeting the southern African region where it first emerged, prompting criticism that the continent was yet again bearing the brunt of panicked policies from Western countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Japan, Israel and Morocco impose bans on all foreign travelers.
description: In Japan, all foreign travelers except those who are residents of the country will be barred from entering starting at midnight on Monday. Morocco went a step further by banning even its citizens.
content: Japan on Monday joined Israel and Morocco in sealing its borders to all foreign travelers in response to the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
title: As China Speeds Up Nuclear Arms Race, the U.S. Wants to Talk
description: The Pentagon thinks Beijing may build 1,000 or more weapons by 2030. But it’s the new technologies that worry strategists.
content: The United States has no nuclear hotline to Beijing. The two countries have never had an in-depth, serious conversation about American missile defenses in the Pacific, or China’s experiments to blind U.S. satellites in time of conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Jennifer Nettles Had Sung ‘She Used to Be Mine.’ But Not While Crying.
description: The country singer and musical-theater fan was grateful to play the intense title role in “Waitress” not long after her Broadway-themed album came out.
content: Sara Bareilles and Jennifer Nettles have been friends for over a decade, and Nettles had long been itching to step into Bareilles’s musical “Waitress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: As U.K. Beckons Truck Drivers, Many in Poland Say ‘No Thanks’
description: A special visa offer, aimed at forestalling a supply chain fiasco during the holidays, goes begging for takers.
content: In the weeks since the British government announced that it would offer 5,000 temporary visas to truck drivers from continental Europe, part of a campaign to reduce supply chain pressure in the run-up to Christmas, Lukasz Skopinski, a Polish trucker now working in the United Kingdom, has offered this advice to friends back home:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 29, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Concerts are returning to South Korea, but fans aren’t allowed to sing along.
description: South Koreans including K-pop fans will not be able to shout, chant or sing at performances with 500 or more attendees, according to government rules.
content: At the first BTS concert of the coronavirus era on Saturday, Maggie Larin, 25, and her three friends were surrounded by a roaring crowd of 70,000 other fans in SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Vartabedian
title: Years of Delays, Billions in Overruns: The Dismal History of Big Infrastructure
description: The nation’s most ambitious engineering projects are mired in postponements and skyrocketing costs. Delivering $1.2 trillion in new infrastructure will be tough.
content: As Honolulu sprawled into new suburbs west of Pearl Harbor over the last two decades, city planners proposed an ambitious rail transit line that would sweep riders 20 miles into downtown. The $4 billion estimate in 2006 was hardly cheap, amounting to $200 million per mile.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Eyes Landed on Something I Didn’t Know I Was Looking For’
description: Unleashed on Third Avenue, a museum encounter and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: A soccer game in Portugal is abandoned after Covid reduces one team to 9 players.
description: Players from the Belenenses team criticized sporting officials for demanding the match go on, saying soccer had “lost its heart.”
content: A top-flight soccer game in Portugal produced instead farcical drama on Saturday evening, after one of the teams was forced to field only nine players, including two goalkeepers, because the rest of its squad had been depleted by a Covid-19 outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: You Can Make Any Day the Best Day of the Year
description: A thought experiment for finding more happiness in the everyday.
content: On New Year’s Eves when I was in my late 20s, I would ask my friends to reflect on our best days of the year, the times when we had the most fun, felt the most grateful or were happiest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Virgil Abloh, Barrier-Breaking Designer, Is Dead at 41
description: His expansive approach to design inspired comparisons to artists including Andy Warhol and Jeff Koons. For him, clothes were totems of identity.
content: Virgil Abloh, the barrier-breaking Black designer whose ascent to the heights of the traditional luxury industry changed what was possible in fashion, died on Sunday in Chicago after a two-year battle with cardiac angiosarcoma, a rare cancer. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Jenny Gross
title: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
description: Two months after concerns about gas and food stocks caused ripples of anxiety, Britain continues to face problems in its supply chain. Distributors and retailers are looking for creative fixes.
content: TILBURY, England — It is called the “wine train,” and every weekend it rumbles out of the port of Tilbury, east of London, on a 100-mile journey to a depot in central England. It looks pretty much like any other freight train, but it carries an unusual cargo: Almost 650,000 bottles of wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Léontine Gallois
title: In a Nonbinary Pronoun, France Sees a U.S. Attack on the Republic
description: When a French dictionary included the gender-nonspecific “iel” for the first time, a virulent reaction erupted over “wokisme” exported from American universities.
content: PARIS — Perhaps France was always going to have a hard time with nonbinary pronouns. Its language is intensely gender-specific and fiercely protected by august authorities. Still, the furor provoked by a prominent dictionary’s inclusion of the pronoun “iel” has been remarkably virulent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: For Ku Stevens, Running Is a ‘Profound Act’
description: This fall, Ku Stevens became the fastest cross-country runner in Nevada. But he would be running even if he wasn’t winning.
content: Watching Ku Stevens fly along the cross-country course in Nevada was like watching a movie play out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The U.K. health secretary rejects calls for new restrictions as more cases of the Omicron variant are found.
description: The government stopped short of urging people to work from home or extending vaccine passports in England after cases of the Omicron variant were detected.
content: The British health secretary, Sajid Javid, rejected calls for tougher restrictions on daily life on Sunday as the new Omicron coronavirus variant continued to spread in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Swiss voters approve their government’s Covid policy in a referendum.
description: After weeks of heated debate and protests, voters backed using Covid certificates that are required to enter public spaces.
content: A majority of Swiss voters backed the government’s Covid-19 response policy in a referendum held on Sunday, following weeks of vitriolic public debate and protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Fetal Viability, Long an Abortion Dividing Line, Faces a Supreme Court Test
description: On Wednesday, the justices will hear the most important abortion case in decades, one that could undermine or overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: WASHINGTON — In 1973, in Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court drew a line. The Constitution, it said, did not allow states to ban abortions before the fetus could survive outside the womb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Take a moment after the holiday, if you can, to catch your breath.
content: Good morning. You holding up? The run-up to Thanksgiving, the holiday itself, entertaining people who’ve traveled great distances to stay with you or traveling great distances to stay with others and entertaining them — the whole thing can be exhausting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Long Live “Wokeness”!’ Or Is It Doomed?
description: On John McWhorter’s call for a new term and Bret Stephens’s assertion that wokeness will fail. Also: Maternal health; American exceptionalism; Facebook.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
